title: Father Brown season 13: cast, plot and everything we know
creator: David Hollingsworth
description: A familiar face returns as Father Brown cracks more cases
content: Father Brown season 13 is on the way with a Father Brown first as they go for a trip to the seaside! Let's hope he's packed his trunks!Filming recently completed on the new series, which sees Mark Williams return as the crime-busting clergyman based on the classic character created by GK Chesterton.Mark says: "My Dad was a surveyor and taught me how to look at buildings, not just their architecture but how they were used, and why they were where they are. So one of the constant pleasures of filming Father Brown for me is the places we film in, and I always have the relevant Pevsner’s ‘Buildings of England’ book to hand."This year, our 13th, has been a great year for interesting locations. We have filmed in The Chateaux Impney a French fantasy in Droitwich, the little theatre in Chipping Norton (an ex Salvation Army Citadel), the wonderful 18th Century octagonal Crown Courts in Warwick and an atmospheric ex-Nunnery in Great Malvern with a glorious chapel by Ninian Comper."Also, The Fleece Inn in Bretforton which is a English pub time capsule, the spectacular Baroque church at Great Witley, and to top it off a selection of lovely stone Cotswold houses and churches. What a fabulous itinerary. And we filmed an episode at the seaside! Lucky lad, as my Dad would have said."Here's everything we know about the new series...Father Brown season 13 release date(Image credit: BBC)Father Brown season 13 is likely to be released on BBC1 in January 2026, although this is still to be confirmed. It's likely to hit BritBox in the US around the same time.Father Brown season 13 cast Mrs McCarthy makes a surprise return (Image credit: BBC)Well the exciting news is Sorcha Cusack will be making a special return as Mrs McCarthy for the first episode! Mrs McCarthy is a great character so it will be nice to have her back. Mark Williams of course stars again as Father Brown.Tom Chambers returns as Inspector Sullivan with Claudie Blakley as the new Mrs Isabel Sullivan, Ruby-May Martinwood as Brenda and John Burton as Sergeant Goodfellow. Also back are Nancy Carroll as Lady Felicia, John Light as Hercule Flambeau, Lex Shrapnel as Father Lazarus, Roger May as Canon Fox and Kieran Hodgson as Father Lindsey.The guest stars include Maureen Lipman, Julia Sawalha, Phil Daniels, Debra Stephenson, Davood Ghadami, Kevin Harvey, George Rainsford and Timothy Watson.Father Brown season 13 plotTeasing the plot, the BBC says: "The new Mr and Mrs Sullivan settle into married life and a new home, with Isabel thrilled to be welcomed into the Policeman’s Wives Society. Meanwhile, Brenda goes on a journey of self-empowerment as she covers the role of Parish Secretary and learns to drive with the help of Sergeant Goodfellow."Father Brown is tasked by Flambeau to visit Father Lazarus in prison, resulting in a deadly game of cat and mouse which ruffles the feathers of Canon Fox. With his consecration now looming, Bishop-Elect Fox plans to enact his revenge upon Father Brown, leaving Kembleford changed forever."Is there a trailer?No, not yet.

title: Orban compares EU disinformation campaign against Hungary to Trump-Russiagate saga
creator: TASS
description: The Hungarian prime minister previously stated that the EU leadership was trying to discredit the Hungarian government with the aim of installing a political opposition in the country that would be obedient to Brussels
content: BUDAPEST, August 8. /TASS/. The leadership of the European Union is using the same disinformation methods against the Hungarian government that the Democratic administration of the United States used against Republican Donald Trump, accusing him of collusion with Russia during the presidential election in 2016, Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban said, commenting on the investigation launched by the US Department of Justice on the Kossuth radio program. "This is a real political bombshell," he said regarding the conclusions of the US authorities that the charges against Trump were fabricated by the Barack Obama administration. According to him, the move was meant to smear the Republican candidate and justify Democratic rival Hillary Clinton’s loss in the election. Orban emphasized that this happened with the participation of the federal authorities and "using government institutions." More recently, the Democratic administration of the United States and George Soros’s foundation used the same methods against the Hungarian government, using "paid media." "Now Brussels is taking a page out of their book," the prime minister said. He had previously stated that the EU leadership was trying to discredit the Hungarian government with the aim of installing a political opposition in the country that would be obedient to Brussels. In 2016, US secret services accused Russia of interfering in the US election, and the media published unconfirmed accusations of collusion between Trump and Moscow. In the United States, an investigation was conducted under the leadership of Special Prosecutor Robert Mueller, which ended in April 2019, finding no evidence of collusion between Trump and Russia. After Trump returned to the White House in 2025, new information emerged about the falsification of data on the basis of which charges were brought against him. In early July, the New York Post mentioned a CIA report that pointed to irregularities and political motivation in the case. US Attorney General Pam Bondi ordered a new investigation, and Trump said the false charges against him were the "crime of the century." On August 1, he announced on Truth Social that the charges had been refuted. The president urged punishment for those responsible.

Speaking from Budapest, Orban suggested that similar strategies aimed at undermining his government's credibility could also be seen within the EU context, drawing parallels to past U.S. investigations into President Trump's ties with Russia.

During a broadcast on Kossuth radio, Orban criticized what he perceives as a concerted attempt by EU leaders to install a pro-Brussels political opposition in Hungary. 'This is a real political bombshell,' Orban remarked after learning of the US Department of Justice's findings suggesting that previous charges against former President Donald Trump may have been politically motivated fabrications by the Obama administration. Orban drew attention to the use of paid media and governmental resources in these endeavors, noting that such tactics now appear to be replicated by Brussels. His comments come amid ongoing discussions about the integrity of democratic processes influenced by foreign interference narratives. In 2016, Russian involvement in the US election led to widespread speculation and subsequent legal scrutiny spearheaded by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, culminating in a lack of conclusive evidence linking Trump to Russian entities. However, revelations later surfaced questioning the veracity of some key pieces of evidence presented during the investigation.

title: Yukon to hold plebiscite on ranked-ballot voting
creator: CTVNews
description: Yukon is gearing up for a territorial election later this year and this time around, the voting system itself is on the ballot.
content: Yukon is gearing up for a territorial election later this year and this time around, the voting system itself is on the ballot. This year’s election will feature a plebiscite on whether the territory should continue to elect leaders through first-past-the-post (FPTP), the system currently in use across Canada, or to adopt a different set of rules. “This non-binding vote does not result in an immediate change but helps to gauge what Yukoners think about potentially changing the voting system,” reads a release from the territory published Thursday. “The Government of Yukon will continue to remain neutral during this process.” The move comes following a yearslong committee review of the territory’s voting system. In its final report last fall, the Yukon Citizens’ Assembly on Electoral Reform recommended replacing FPTP with a ranked vote system, wherein voters choose multiple candidates in order of who they would most prefer to win, and those second, third and other choices are factored in. Under the current FPTP system, the candidate in each race with the largest number of votes wins, regardless of whether they secure a majority. Meanwhile, in a ranked-voting election, if no candidate wins a majority, then the candidate with the fewest votes is eliminated from the running and their votes are redistributed based on who each voter chose as their second choice. This process repeats until a candidate passes the majority threshold, and a winner is declared. FPTP remains in use for the vast majority of Canadian elections, but ranked-ballot systems do commonly appear in leadership races for political parties, and occasionally in municipal votes. In 2018, the City of London, Ont., held a mayoral race by ranked-choice vote, but two years later, the province outlawed ranked ballots in future municipal elections.
ai_summary: Yukon plans a plebiscite before its upcoming election to decide between continuing with the first-past-the-post voting system or switching to a ranked-ballot system. The government has remained neutral while reviewing recommendations from the Citizens' Assembly that suggest adopting ranked voting, which could impact how winners are determined in close races.
ai_content:
In preparation for the forthcoming territorial election, Yukon Territory officials have announced a plebiscite concerning the adoption of a new voting system. Voters will soon face a decision regarding the continuation of the existing first-past-the-post (FPTP) electoral method used throughout Canada versus transitioning to a ranked-ballot system. The proposed shift aims to address concerns raised after extensive deliberation by the Yukon Citizens’ Assembly on Electoral Reform, whose final report suggested moving away from FPTP due to potential issues such as unrepresentative outcomes when no single candidate achieves a majority.
Under the current FPTP framework, only the highest vote-getter in each constituency secures victory, irrespective of achieving more than half of the total votes cast. Conversely, the ranked-voting model allows citizens to rank candidates according to preference, ensuring that even minority-supported candidates contribute to determining the ultimate victor once subsequent preferences are considered.
The plebiscite represents a preliminary step towards gauging public opinion rather than enacting immediate changes; however, it underscores the government's commitment to exploring alternative democratic processes within the region. As part of this initiative, Yukon residents will weigh in on whether altering the voting mechanism aligns with their vision for fairer representation and governance.
While FPTP dominates Canadian federal elections, ranked ballots find occasional application at party leader selection events and some local elections—such as London's mayoral contest in Ontario—which was conducted using this system in 2018. However, legislative action taken subsequently prohibited further utilization of ranked ballots in municipal contexts there.
As Yukon approaches this pivotal moment in its electoral history, stakeholders await insights into the community's stance on reforming one of Canada's foundational political practices.

title: Not so like-minded after all
creator: MurielVieux
description: One of the worse feelings in this current state of affairs, is the casual dismissal by allies and those considered like minded folks of issues they think do not concern them. It’s having them insist on telling you why you are wrong about the issues you live with every day, while asking you to rally around the causes that matter to them. The realization that a lot of people on our side do not in reality care about righting wrongs that don’t affect them, about restoring rights they already enjoy, it is the slow dawning comprehension that for all intents and purposes a lot of our allies will not stand by us, unless there’s something in it for them. I confess, personally it makes me feel depressed at times, but frustration is my constant companion. If I can’t convince folks on my side that my issues matter, how the hell will I ever convince the other side? How will they ever change? Grow? When allies tell you “you are preaching to the choir” do they realize they have just said they have “black fatigue”? They are tired of hearing about our issues? Telling us that the Jeans/Gene commercial was “just a play on words” is akin to telling us “stop exaggerating” “not everything is about race”? I don’t think they realize the import nor the underlying meaning of their words. Imagine getting in an multi car accident, going to the hospital and all the doctors keep examining the scratches on the hands and faces of victims one after the other as you lay there telling them your leg with the bone sticking out hurts, and have them tell you, yes we see your leg, we can see its broken, we know it hurts, but it’s easier to get these lesser hurt people out first, then we’ll get to you. That’s how I feel at times trying to get through to some people. Since tacoman came on the political scene there have been over 1000 bills and laws, proposed and passed, that have rescinded minority rights, whitewashed history, data, archives, practices etc... everything from Affirmative Action to Rosa Part has been diluted or remove. Not one single bill passed in that same period by the first or second taco administration has uplifted the economy (quite the contrary), but allies still tell us “it’s is about the economy stupid” it’s abot “working class issues” as they try and justify why the not maga voted for taco. We’ve had don’t say gay bills, anti-trans bills, don’t make our children uncomfortable bills, eliminate abortion bills, ban books bills, erase DEI bills, cancel AA bills, deportation bills, but they still look us straight in the eye and say ‘it’s the economy stupid”. How? Taco talked more about Trans folks, immigrants, Black folks, abortion than he ever did about the economy, on the other hand Harris talked more about economic solutions than cultural issues... yet the narrative is inverted when talk of the election rises up. And for the love of God, don’t go on about low information and they didn’t know or whatever other excuse pops up. The slide towards fascism in red states, the narratives from the right, the bills and laws were in full swing and view since the first round of taco. People were knocking on doors informing voters more than ever before. It is part of that careless dismissal. You want it to be something else so much you can taste it. Anything but that! But it is that. It was that. It will always be that, until corrected. So, I’m sitting here wondering today how is this possible? Are left-learning people just as susceptible to manipulation and propaganda as the right? Are they just as unconcerned by minority issues? Are our allies, those like minded folks really that blind? Do they not see the sheer magnitude of events, actions, bills, laws being enacted against minorities? I know they do, because they comment about them individually for the most part. But it’s like they refuse to face the totality of what’s going on, preferring to pick and choose instances so they don’t have to reckon with reality. The disconnect is baffling, for they talk about white supremacy, they talk about Christian nationalism, they talk about authoritarian state, but when you bring up that the jeans/gene commercial is about race, they say no no no, you’re seeing things that aren’t there. If the issue isn’t race, how is the result white supremacy? Riddle me that one Batman.How do we solve a problem that people refuse to acknowledge? Talk about it, we get backlash, don’t talk about it, makes them happy but it’s swept under the rug and quickly forgotten until the next outrage. So what is a Black US Citizen to do in this climate of persistent denial? One day they are all on your side, yes yes, it’s racism, white supremacy, then an event happens and you say “that’s white supremacy” and they go “No it’s not, it’s just a joke, a play on words” and I’m left scratching my head in utmost confusion.It's the same thing with the “why don’t dems do something” crowd. Every other day I have headlines emblazoned across my recommendations “finally dems are doing something!” then 2 days later again “finally Dems are doing something!” and a 1 or 2 after that “Dems are on the attack!” or some such... do they know what “finally” means? And still in between those headlines, they keep attacking dems. Well the dems they don’t like. Because let’s be real, I’ve yet to see a headline or article asking “why don’t progressives (or independents) do something!”. Personally, I see lots of Dems, Progressives and Independents doing things according to their strength and I’m fine with the fact that their names are not everyday on display. I don’t know folks, as I watch this country rip itself apart from all directions, I can’t help but think about how broken we all seem to be. Most folks don’t seem to care about anything beyond their doorstep, and it is the saddest sight ever. Does it even register that close to 13% of US Citizens, have for all intents and purposes quit? That they’ve been let down so many times they’ve finally stopped trusting you? Stopped believing and most sadly we have stopped hoping? “Someone sent me enough to take care of this month urgencies! Thank you! If others want to help out paypal.me/murielvieux there are always folks needing help and if I can get ahead of next month so much better, but this month is covered so no pressure. I’m not pretending I’m saving the world or even Haiti but I’m helping to keep some folks fed, I choose families with kids as priorities, and that’s good enough for me.“#TheAmericanHaitianPoet #Woke #SocialPoetry Paypal.me/murielvieux (small donations go a long way in Haiti) Muriel Vieux – August 8th, 2025 – ©All rights reserved

Despite numerous legislative efforts aimed at undermining minority protections during the Trump administration, many allies continue to prioritize economic arguments rather than supporting social justice initiatives.
ai_content:
In recent years, individuals within marginalized groups have felt increasingly alienated by what appears to be a lack of genuine support from supposed allies. This sense of betrayal stems from witnessing others trivialize concerns central to their daily lives—concerns such as racial discrimination, gender inequality, and LGBTQ+ rights. Allies often seem more interested in discussing topics unrelated to these pressing matters, leaving advocates frustrated and questioning where true solidarity lies.
This disillusionment became particularly acute following the election of Donald Trump, whose tenure saw over 1000 pieces of legislation introduced or enacted that sought to erode minority rights across various domains—from affirmative action policies to historical recognition. These actions included attempts to dilute or outright repeal measures designed to protect against systemic racism and promote equality.
Despite these significant setbacks, proponents of progressive values continued to argue that broader socioeconomic issues were paramount. However, activists found little solace in these reassurances; instead, they perceived a disconnect between ally rhetoric and tangible support for movements fighting against oppression.
The situation mirrors a scenario where multiple vehicles collide, yet medical attention focuses solely on minor injuries before addressing life-threatening conditions—a metaphor illustrating the neglect experienced by those suffering under oppressive systems. As advocacy continues amidst ongoing challenges, the struggle for understanding and meaningful alliance remains fraught with obstacles.

content: M ehdi Hasan knew he had gone viral. The broadcaster and author saw the views ticking up on YouTube , his phone was pinging incessantly. But the realisation that things had become, well, really quite surreal, came when an older gentleman approached him at an event in Washington and, in Urdu, said: “I watched you with the 20 crazies.” The Guardian’s journalism is independent. We will earn a commission if you buy something through an affiliate link. Learn more . The man was referring to the British-American commentator’s appearance on Surrounded , a gladiatorial one-v-many debate web series, hosted on YouTube by Jubilee Media. During the debate – billed as “ 1 Progressive vs 20 Far-Right Conservatives ” – Hasan was asked about his “ethnic background”, by a man who the Guardian unmasked as the organiser of two violent far-right protests . Another debater laughed maniacally to applause while agreeing he was a fascist (he was later sacked, condemned – and then raised $30,000 (£22,300) from supporters on a Christian crowdfunding site). The video has now been viewed more than 10m times. “I saw the massive audience it gets with young people. I thought, well, that’s a good place to be,” says Hasan , who launched Zeteo, his own alternative news platform, last year. “But it’s really cut through in a way even I didn’t imagine – it’s been phenomenal for both good reasons and bad.” Hasan’s near two-hour debate – diced, sliced and repackaged for infinite resharing – has propelled Jubilee Media into the mainstream consciousness, sparking conversations about the political and societal impact of new media formats, and plenty of existential angst. Launched in 2017, the rapidly expanding entertainment company has attracted swathes of younger viewers by transforming polarised debate – never in short supply in Trump’s US – into eminently clippable content. The company also produces dating and game shows, but Surrounded – which pits one expert against a greater number of adversaries, who race to a single chair to make their point on a hot political topic – is its most notorious. In recent months Surrounded has gone where few traditional broadcasters would care to tread, with titles including “Flat Earthers vs Scientists: Can We Trust Science?” (31m views), or “Can 25 Liberal College Students Outsmart 1 Conservative? (Feat. Charlie Kirk)” (30m views). Its 2024 video with Ben Shapiro – in which a trans man tore into the rightwing pundit in a four-minute rant – was the fifth most-watched election-related content on YouTube. Its founder and chief executive, Jason Y Lee, who started Jubilee as a non-profit in 2010 after a video of him busking for charity went viral , told Variety that the company wants “to show what discourse can and should look like”. It could become, he argued, the “Disney for empathy”. But how does its performative pugilism sit with its stated aim to “provoke understanding and create human connection”? Spencer Kornhaber, who writes about popular culture for the Atlantic, believes the idealism is genuine, if shot through with ambition. “Empathy, in the Jubilee context, is standing for voyeurism and curiosity about other human beings,” says Kornhaber. “Lee didn’t say he wants to be the new UN. He wants to be Disney – a for-profit entertainment company that is culturally ubiquitous, will merchandise anything and is known for its ability to spin out franchises.” Jubilee has benefited from the proliferation of free-speech absolutism, as well as the internet’s shift to social and video, says Julia Alexander, a media correspondent for Puck News. But while it may have started with the aim of transforming negative conversations, it has, she claims, “succumbed to the hateful vitriol that defines a lot of social media”. It never stood a chance against the “unspoken but understood currency of the internet”, she adds: namely, that rage-fuelled and fearful content provokes more engagement than empathy or actually listening. “I hope that they choose to focus on creating positive content for the internet, God knows we can use it,” she says. “But I worry, because they are a company that is incentivised to continuously scale and perform better each quarter. They’ll have no choice but to continue doing more of these types of videos and just get more extreme.” Hasan, who is also a Guardian contributor, says he understands viewers’ attraction to the more extreme videos Jubilee has produced. The author of Win Every Argument, a book about the art of debating, he argues that traditional media deserted the battlefield, allowing platforms such as YouTube – now the No 1 source of televised entertainment in the US – to commandeer the space. “Mainstream media did such a shit job of facilitating debate and discussion and [giving a platform to] people with unorthodox views,” he says. “But I do think it’s a balancing act between the two extremes. Between censorship and narrowing of opinion and no standards at all, no guardrails, just put out anything you like on YouTube as long as it gets clicks.” He also understands – even agrees with – some of the criticism he has faced for going on Surrounded. The writer and disability rights advocate Imani Barbarin argued that while clips of Hasan’s takedown of far-right extremists were shared by progressives trumpeting his “win”, an equal number were shared as proof he lost. “We live in a meme-ified culture of politics,” said Barbarin, in a post on X . “Those moments are quite literally being plucked out of space and time [...] the surrounding context of that moment no longer matters.” Hasan says if he has regrets, it was that he did not find out more about the people he was facing, arguing that such extremists would be among them. But whether he regrets taking part overall? The jury is out. “I stand by what I said. I think I did a fair enough job as a debater,” he says. “The bigger meta question is whether the format itself is a problem. Is there value in doing these debates? And I don’t know the answer to that: maybe ask me in five years.”

title: Will Rahul Gandhi's 'vote theft' attack on Election Commission undercut INDIA bloc's SIR stance in Bihar?
creator: Rajeev Singh
description: Rahul Gandhi has accused the Election Commission of India (ECI) of electoral roll lapses in Karnataka, presenting documents as evidence of "vote chori." content: Photo: Generative AI NEW DELHI: Rahul Gandhi , long a fierce critic of the Election Commission of India (ECI), on Thursday presented what he called “criminal evidence” to back his “vote chori” charge in recent polls that left the Congress in tatters. In his presentation, the Lok Sabha leader of opposition alleged serious lapses in the electoral rolls of Mahadevapura assembly constituency, part of the Bangalore Central Lok Sabha seat in Congress-ruled Karnataka. During a press briefing, Gandhi displayed a spiral-bound stack of documents, which he said were drawn from the “7-foot pile” of electoral rolls provided by the ECI. He alleged that votes were stolen in five ways : duplicate votes, fake or invalid addresses, bulk voters at a single address, invalid photos, and misuse of Form 6 (application to add a name to the voter list in India). Rahul Gandhi with his "proof" at the press briefing. Interestingly, just as Rahul presented his “proof,” the Karnataka chief electoral officer wrote to him, seeking the material he had shown to the nation along with an oath-bound declaration, as a prerequisite for the probe to begin. The poll body’s letter seeking Rahul’s declaration gave the rival BJP fresh ammunition, which accused the Congress leader of “threating the institution” and claimed that by flagging loopholes in the electoral rolls, the Raebareli MP had effectively endorsed the Special Intensive Revision (SIR) in Bihar, which aims to tighten loose ends in the poll rolls. Rahul Gandhi briefing the INDIA bloc allies at his house. (PTI photo) Will Rahul submit a declaration? Rahul Gandhi did not appear to budge on the EC notice, saying: "I'm saying it publicly to everybody. Take it as an oath. This is their data, and we are displaying their data. This is not our data." Rahul Gandhi with a document, which he claimed has a compilation of fake and invalid addresses enrolled in the electoral roll of Mahadevapura assembly constituency. (PTI photo) On whether the Congress leader would submit a declaration to the ECI, Congress leader Udit Raj told TOI: "The Election Commission will try to find certain things in that, whether right or wrong. Then the BJP will take over that, and finally, they'll try to dilute it. Why is the Election Commission not answering? Why will CCTV footage be destroyed in 45 days when data can be stored for 100 years? " He was referring to ECI's order to state poll officers to destroy election CCTV, webcasting, and video footage 45 days after the results, if no court challenge is filed. Rahul Gandhi Releases New Video, Claims More 'Proof' On EC, BJP Collusion in Voter List Fraud When asked if the Congress party would move the Supreme Court in case the deadlock with the Election Commission continues, the former Lok Sabha MP said: "Our court is public. The way one judge has made a frivolous and strange comment about Rahul Gandhi. BJP MP has said that China has encroached on the land. Ladakh people are crying, even satellite pictures have shown how much land has been encroached, and here the judge says: Give the proof. What to do? If there are certain judges like these, what to do? They will turn down. " However, he added, "definitely we believe in the institutions, provided that the institutions give justice. Institutions were created by Congress, but when institutions are subverted and pressure is built, then, of course, we have to fight, and finally, there's a people's court, which is the highest court for a political party. On the question of whether the INDIA bloc would boycott the upcoming election if the issue remains unresolved, he said: "We will resort to all kinds of methodologies to fight it out. Any option which is available within the framework of democracy, we will exercise that." Did the BJP 'collude' with ECI? Responding to Rahul Gandhi's "ECI colluding with BJP" charge, national BJP spokesperson Pradeep Bhandari told TOI: "If ECI was colluding with the BJP, Rahul Gandhi would not have won his seat in Amethi, his sister would not have won her seat in Wayanad. Congress party government would not have been there in Telangana, Karnataka and the opposition government in Jharkhand and Tamil Nadu." When asked if the ECI should probe into Rahul's claim, even if he refuses to submit the declaration, Bhandari said: "That is under the purview of the wisdom of the Election Commission." He, however, added that in case the Congress leader refuses to submit the declaration along with his "proof", it would become clear that Rahul Gandhi has "lied again". "The Election Commission has asked Rahul Gandhi for an oath, and if he doesn't give in writing it will be clear that, like he lied about Rafale, China-occupied Indian territory...Rahul Gandhi is yet again lying because he wants to divert attention from his imminent loss in Bihar," Pradeep Bhandari told TOI. Will SIR now get the INDIA bloc's nod? The opposition INDIA bloc has vehemently criticised the intensive roll revision in Bihar, questioning the timing of the exercise and the alleged "haste" with which the entire process is being conducted in the poll-bound state. "We are questioning the timing. 35 BLOs are sitting in one place, and they are filling up the form. So 70 per cent of voters have not been approved. On their behalf, forms have been filled up and are incomplete. In some places, " Trump and Dogbabu's " names have appeared. Not even one booth is perfect," Udit Raj alleged. Donald Trump, Shri Ram, Kaua (Crow) As Bihar Local: Oppn Flags Bizarre Applications In SIR Countering Rahul Gandhi's criticism of SIR, Pradeep Bhandari said: "Earlier, it was EVM, then the voter list went to Maharashtra, where the Bombay high court dismissed the plea. Now, a new thing has come, SIR. In the presentation that Rahul Gandhi showed, even there, Rahul inadvertently became a proponent of SIR rather than opposing it." ALSO READ: ECI questions Rahul Gandhi’s ‘fake votes’ claim; cites Karnataka govt’s use of same rolls for caste census "Let Rahul Gandhi and the RJD go to the voters of Bihar with this as an agenda, we will go with our developmental agenda," he said, adding: "Only person who should worry is Tejashwi Yadav, whose two voter IDs were found, and he is to answer how a leader of the opposition party in Bihar was holding two voter ID cards." Whether Rahul Gandhi’s claims trigger a serious probe or fade into another round of political crossfire now rests in the court of public opinion. Notwithstanding, the episode has become a test of credibility for both sides, with its outcome likely to shape how future challenges to voter lists are addressed and how much trust the public places in the electoral process.

In a significant political development, Rahul Gandhi, the leader of India's main opposition party, the Indian National Congress, leveled accusations against the Election Commission of India (ECI) regarding potential irregularities in the electoral rolls during recent elections in Karnataka. Gandhi's allegations came after the ECI reported discrepancies within the electoral rolls of Mahadevapura assembly constituency—a segment of the larger Bangalore Central Lok Sabha seat—which falls under the jurisdiction of the Congress-led state government. In a press conference held in New Delhi, Gandhi showcased a collection of papers extracted from a substantial volume supplied by the ECI itself. These papers allegedly revealed various forms of vote manipulation including duplicate voting records, fraudulent or invalid residential addresses, concentration of multiple voters at one location, use of incorrect photographs, and improper handling of Form 6 applications used to register new voters.

This request was communicated via written correspondence directed towards Gandhi himself.
The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), currently holding power at the national level, seized upon Gandhi's public accusation as an opportunity to criticize him further. They argued that by bringing attention to flaws within the electoral system, Gandhi was essentially threatening the integrity of the ECI and unintentionally lending support to measures like the Special Intensive Revision (SIR) being implemented in Bihar—a move aimed at rectifying inaccuracies found within election rolls.
Despite facing pressure from both sides—the ECI demanding official declarations and the BJP challenging his motives—Gandhi remained steadfast in his position. He insisted that his intention was merely to highlight genuine concerns about the electoral process rather than undermine the authority of the ECI.

title: Authoritarian rulers aren’t new – here’s what Herodotus, an early Greek historian, wrote about them
creator: Debbie Felton, Professor of Classics, UMass Amherst
description: Herodotus showed how human beliefs and choices affected the fate of nations. His insights are still relevant.
content: Darius I of Persia, center, and his court, from a vase painted between 340 and 320 B.C.E., on display at the National Archaeological Museum in Naples. Carlo Raso/ Flickr, CC BY-SA“No Kings” rallies. “Good Trouble” protests. “Rage against the Regime” uprisings. These events in the first seven months of President Donald Trump’s second term, along with public opinion polls, show that many Americans are concerned about Trump’s expansive use of executive power.Views on this issue often have a partisan slant. Republicans express more concern about presidential power when Democrats control the White House, and vice versa. But many in both parties prefer that U.S. political leaders work through established channels, rather than through unconventional actions that may pose challenges to the Constitution and the rule of law, such as mass firings and large-scale deportations. Greek historian and ethnographer Herodotus lived from about 484 B.C.E. to about 425 B.C.E. Metropolitan Museum of Art/Wikimedia As a professor of classics, I know that concerns about authoritarianism go back thousands of years. One early discussion appears in the work of the fifth-century B.C.E. Greek writer Herodotus, whose “History” – sometimes called “Histories” – is considered the first great prose narrative in Western literature. In it, Herodotus analyzed the Persian invasion of Greece – the defining event of his time. To understand how Greece, a much smaller power, achieved a major victory over Persia, Herodotus explored the nature of effective leadership, which he saw as a critical factor in the conflict’s outcome.A shocking upsetPersia was already a vast empire when it invaded Greece, a tiny country made up of independent city-states. The Persians expected a quick and easy victory. Instead, the Greco-Persian Wars lasted over a decade, from 490 to 479 B.C.E. They ended with Greece defeating the Persians – a shocking upset. Consequently, Persia abandoned its westward expansion, while various Greek city-states formed a tenuous alliance that lasted nearly 50 years.To explain this unexpected outcome, Herodotus described how Persian and Greek societies developed before this crucial conflict. In his view, the fact that many Greek city-states had representative governments enabled the Greek victory. These systems allowed individuals to participate in discussing strategies and resulted in the Greeks uniting to fight for freedom. For example, when the Persian fleet was headed toward mainland Greece, the Athenian general Miltiades says, “Never before have we been in such extreme danger. If we give in to the Persians, we will suffer greatly under the tyrant Hippias.”Herodotus tended to put his political philosophies into the mouths of historical figures such as Miltiades. He condensed his thoughts about government into what historians call the “Constitutional Debate,” a fictional conversation among three real characters: Persian noblemen named Otanes, Megabazus and Darius. A fragment from Herodotus’ ‘Histories,’ Book VIII, on papyrus, dated to the early second century C.E. Sackler Library, Oxford/Wikimedia Persia’s ascentFor centuries prior to invading Greece, Persia had been a small region inhabited by various ancient Iranian peoples and controlled by the neighboring kingdom of Media. Then, in 550 B.C.E., King Cyrus II of Persia overthrew the Medes and expanded Persian territory into what became the Achaemenid Empire. Thanks to his effective leadership and tolerance for the customs of cultures he conquered, historians call him “Cyrus the Great.”His son and successor, Cambyses, was less successful. He added Egypt to the Persian empire, but according to Herodotus, Cambyses acted erratically and cruelly. He desecrated the pharaoh’s tomb, mocked the Egyptians’ gods, and killed their sacred Apis bull. He also demanded that Persian judges change the laws so that he could marry his own sisters. After Cambyses died childless, various factions vied for the Persian throne. Herodotus set his discussion about alternative political systems in this unstable period. The case for democracyOtanes, the first speaker in the Constitutional Debate, says “the time has passed for any one man among us to have absolute power.” He recommends that the Persian people themselves handle state affairs. “How can monarchy continue to be our norm, when a monarch can do whatever he wants, with no accountability whatsoever?” Otanes asks. Even worse, a monarch “disrupts the laws,” as Cambyses did. Otanes favors rule by the many, which he calls “isonomia,” meaning “equality under the law.” In this system, he explains, politicians are elected and held responsible for their behavior and make decisions transparently. Today, unlike Otanes, Republican members of Congress appear reluctant to hold Trump responsible for anything or ensure transparency within the administration. Prominent Democrats, including U.S. Rep. Jamie Raskin and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, are challenging Trump administration actions that they view as lawless, such as freezing of funds authorized by Congress.Do oligarchs know better?Otanes’ fellow nobleman, Megabazus, agrees that the Persians should abolish monarchy, but he raises concerns about rule by the people. “The masses are useless – there’s nothing more witless and violent than a crowd,” Megabazus asserts. He believes “commoners” don’t understand the intricacies of policymaking. Instead, Megabazus suggests oligarchy, or “rule by a few.” Choose the best men in Persia and let them rule everyone else, he urges, because they “will naturally come up with the best ideas.” But Megabazus doesn’t explain who would qualify as “the best men” or who would select them.The U.S. has occasionally resembled an oligarchy, with small, elite groups holding most political power. For example, Article 1, Section 3 of the original Constitution provided for election of senators by state legislators, not directly by the people. Senators were not elected by popular vote until the 17th Amendment passed in 1913. More recently, Trump has received millions of dollars in support from billionaire tech industry leaders such as Elon Musk, Mark Zuckerberg and Jeff Bezos, who hope to influence antitrust policy and deregulation. The Department of Government Efficiency, headed by Musk before he stepped down in May 2025, is now run by young men with virtually no government experience. DOGE’s cuts to programs such as humanitarian aid are wreaking havoc across the globe.What about monarchy?The third speaker, Darius, sees democracy and oligarchy as equally flawed. He points out that even well-intentioned oligarchs fight among themselves because “each wants his own opinion to prevail.” This leads to hatred and worse, much like the Trump-Musk relationship gone sour.Rather, Darius asserts, “using good judgment, a monarch will be a flawless guardian of the people.” He argues that since Persia was freed by one man, King Cyrus II, Persians should maintain their traditional monarchy. Darius doesn’t explain how to ensure a monarch’s good judgment. But his argument wins out. It had to, since in reality Darius became Persia’s next king. Kings, or shahs, ruled Persia – it became known as Iran in 1935 – until the Iranian Revolution of 1979 eliminated the monarchy and established the Islamic Republic of Iran. Trump is not technically a monarch, but some believe he acts like one. He and his administration have ignored court orders, preempted the powers of Congress and sought to silence his critics by attacking protected free speech. Protesters carry a banner representing the preamble to the U.S. Constitution in downtown Los Angeles during an anti-Trump demonstration on June 14, 2025. Mario Tama/Getty Images Lessons from HerodotusHerodotus himself was largely pro-democracy, but his Constitutional Debate doesn’t endorse one form of government. Instead, it highlights principles of good leadership. These include accountability, moderation and respect for “nomos,” a Greek term encompassing the concepts of custom and law. Herodotus emphasizes: “Formerly great cities have become small, while small cities have become great.” Human fortune changes constantly, and Persia’s failure to conquer Greece is just one example. History has seen the rise and fall of many world powers. Is the United States next? Herodotus viewed the Persian monarchy, whose kings believed their own authority was paramount, as the weakness that led to their astounding defeat in 479 B.C.E.Debbie Felton is affiliated with the Democratic Party (registered to vote).
ai_summary: Herodotus, an ancient Greek historian, provided insight into the rise of authoritarian rulers and their impact on nations' fates. During President Trump's second term's initial seven months, 'No Kings,' 'Good Trouble,' and 'Rage against the Regime' movements highlighted American concerns regarding Trump's extensive use of executive power. Partisan views influence perceptions of presidential authority, yet there is bipartisan preference for traditional governance methods. Herodotus' analysis of the Persian-Greek wars emphasized the importance of leadership in determining historical outcomes.
ai_content:
In the annals of history, authoritarian regimes have been a recurring theme, one that even the ancient Greek historian Herodotus addressed centuries ago. Living around 484 to 425 B.C.E., Herodotus chronicled significant events like the Persian invasion of Greece—a pivotal moment that shaped his era. His seminal work, known as 'The Histories,' delves deep into the dynamics of leadership and its profound effect on national destinies.
Fast forward to modern times, during President Donald Trump's tenure, particularly in his second term's first half, America witnessed numerous demonstrations under banners such as 'No Kings,' 'Good Trouble,' and 'Rage against the Regime.' These gatherings reflected widespread apprehension towards Trump's broad exercise of executive powers. Public sentiment on this matter tends to align with party lines; however, across the aisle, there's a shared inclination among citizens favoring conventional democratic processes over radical measures potentially threatening constitutional integrity and legal norms.
This dichotomy echoes sentiments expressed millennia earlier by Herodotus. As a classicist scholar specializing in antiquity, I've observed that anxieties concerning autocratic tendencies aren't novel—they've persisted throughout history. Herodotus himself scrutinized these themes within his magnum opus, exploring not just military conquests but also societal structures and governance models.
His account begins with Persia—an empire sprawling across continents—clashing with Greece, a coalition of small city-states. Contrary to expectations of swift conquest, the protracted Greco-Persian Wars spanned ten years (490–479 B.C.E.), culminating in a surprising triumph for Greece. This defeat forced Persia to halt its western ambitions and prompted disparate Greek states to forge alliances enduring almost five decades.
To comprehend why such an unlikely victory occurred, Herodotus examined pre-war developments in both empires. He posited that the Greeks' relatively advanced systems of representation played a role in their resilience and success.

title: Donald Trump estranged their family. Talking about him brought them back together.
creator: USA TODAY
description: A 2024 survey found 1 in 5 Americans have become estranged from a family member due to disagreements on controversial topics.
content: Haley Popp has always had a close relationship with her mom . The 44-year-old from Flower Mound, Texas, respectfully disagreed with her mother’s conservative views . But they could always set aside their political differences to connect. That changed in 2016. Haley’s parents, Mary Lou and Bob Kultgen, became avid supporters of President Donald Trump and his call to “Make America Great Again.” Haley and her brother, Chad Kultgen, disagreed. Vehemently. The political tension reached its peak during the pandemic. Every conversation Haley and Chad had with their parents turned into a fight over politics. They blocked each other on social media. Haley went from speaking on the phone with her mother every day to going months without talking. “I always considered my mom one of my best friends... It was sad,” Haley said. “It was a hard time. I thought I might not be able to talk to my parents again.” “It was ripping my heart out,” said Mary Lou, 70, who lives in Edmond, Oklahoma. Their situation was not unlike many family dynamics in the U.S. They later found a way to repair theirs. A survey conducted before the 2024 presidential election found that 1 in 5 Americans had become estranged from a family member, blocked a family member on social media or skipped a family event due to disagreements over controversial topics such as politics, according to the American Psychiatric Association. “Our current environment has become increasingly polarized,” APA CEO and medical director Dr. Marketa Wills said in October 2024. “Some of us will find ourselves having heated conversations and disagreements on sensitive issues, even with the people we are close to. Sometimes these discussions represent healthy debate, and other times they may cross the line into incivility if emotions flare.” In 2022, Chad decided he had had enough. He didn’t know how much time he had left with his parents and he didn’t want to spend those remaining years estranged. If the only way he could speak to his parents was fighting over politics, he said, then bring it on. “The only time we could lock in was by talking politics,” said Chad, 44, who lives in Los Angeles. “I thought why not do this as a podcast because it would regiment the need for us to get together every week for one hour.” Read up: Gen Z men, women have a deep political divide. It's made dating a nightmare He approached Haley with the idea. She said to herself, “We have nothing to lose, so why not?” The podcast, dubbed “The Necessary Conversation Podcast,” ended up saving the family. Bickering on the podcast for an hour every Sunday allowed them to focus on other things outside of the show. If anyone mentioned politics during a family gathering or casual phone call, Chad encouraged them to “save it for the podcast," which he called their "therapy." “That’s our one hour for yipping and fighting and going after each other,” Mary Lou said. “The podcast is only a sliver of our real lives and what we mean to each other.” In case you missed: What do moms really want for Mother's Day? We need to talk about it. Now, the siblings visit their parents’ barn in Oklahoma and attend Kansas State University football games together. Haley even helped her father during his recovery from a second hip surgery. They still don’t agree on politics, but they’ve learned to listen to one another and sympathize. Chad hopes he can show other families that it's possible to repair familial relationships despite political differences. "My relationship with my parents was more important than my relationship wth Donald Trump ," he said. Mary Lou agreed. "Politics is not worth losing family members over or losing the love for your family," she said. "It's just not worth it." Adrianna Rodriguez can be reached at adrodriguez@usatoday.com. title: Donald Trump estranged their family. Talking about him brought them back together.

content: Haley Popp has always had a close relationship with her mom . The 44-year-old from Flower Mound, Texas, respectfully disagreed with her mother’s conservative views . But they could always set aside their political differences to connect. That changed in 2016. Haley’s parents, Mary Lou and Bob Kultgen, became avid supporters of President Donald Trump and his call to “Make America Great Again.” Haley and her brother, Chad Kultgen, disagreed. Vehemently. The political tension reached its peak during the pandemic. Every conversation Haley and Chad had with their parents turned into a fight over politics. They blocked each other on social media. Haley went from speaking on the phone with her mother every day to going months without talking. “I always considered my mom one of my best friends... It was sad,” Haley said. “It was a hard time. I thought I might not be able to talk to my parents again.” “It was ripping my heart out,” said Mary Lou, 70, who lives in Edmond, Oklahoma. Their situation was not unlike many family dynamics in the U.S. They later found a way to repair theirs. A survey conducted before the 2024 presidential election found that 1 in 5 Americans had become estranged from a family member, blocked a family member on social media or skipped a family event due to disagreements over controversial topics such as politics, according to the American Psychiatric Association. “Our current environment has become increasingly polarized,” APA CEO and medical director Dr. Marketa Wills said in October 2024. “Some of us will find ourselves having heated conversations and disagreements on sensitive issues, even with the people we are close to. Sometimes these discussions represent healthy debate, and other times they may cross the line into incivility if emotions flare.” In 2022, Chad decided he had had enough. He didn’t know how much time he had left with his parents and he didn’t want to spend those remaining years estranged. If the only way he could speak to his parents was fighting over politics, he said, then bring it on. “The only time we could lock in was by talking politics,” said Chad, 44, who lives in Los Angeles. “I thought why not do this as a podcast because it would regiment the need for us to get together every week for one hour.” He approached Haley with the idea. She said to herself, “We have nothing to lose, so why not?” The podcast, dubbed “The Necessary Conversation Podcast,” ended up saving the family. Bickering on the podcast for an hour every Sunday allowed them to focus on other things outside of the show. If anyone mentioned politics during a family gathering or casual phone call, Chad encouraged them to “save it for the podcast," which he called their "therapy." “That’s our one hour for yipping and fighting and going after each other,” Mary Lou said. “The podcast is only a sliver of our real lives and what we mean to each other.” Now, the siblings visit their parents’ barn in Oklahoma and attend Kansas State University football games together. Haley even helped her father during his recovery from a second hip surgery. They still don’t agree on politics, but they’ve learned to listen to one another and sympathize. Chad hopes he can show other families that it's possible to repair familial relationships despite political differences. "My relationship with my parents was more important than my relationship wth Donald Trump ," he said. Mary Lou agreed. "Politics is not worth losing family members over or losing the love for your family," she said. "It's just not worth it." Adrianna Rodriguez can be reached at adrodriguez@usatoday.com.

title: Who owns Gaza? Israel's occupation plans
creator: theweekonlineeditorsuk@futurenet.com (Chas Newkey-Burden, The Week UK)

description: Egypt, Israel and Britain have ruled the beleaguered territory
content: Occupying Gaza is the only way to ensure Israel's security and wipe out Hamas, claimed Benjamin Netanyahu as he announced that the Israeli army will "take control of Gaza City". The UN said that the move risks "catastrophic consequences" for Palestinian civilians and Israeli hostages, and there has also been condemnation from world leaders, the Israeli military and relatives of the hostages. Who owns Gaza? Before Israel was established in 1948, the area now known as Gaza was "part of the large swathe" of the Middle East that was under British colonial rule, said South China Morning Post . Upon the foundation of Israel, 700,000 Palestinians either fled or were forced from their homes. Tens of thousands of them "flocked" to the "strip of land wedged between Israel, Egypt and the Mediterranean Sea", which was handed to the control of the Egyptian army. During the Six-Day War of 1967, Israel took control of Gaza from Egypt and began to build settlements on the land. Then, after Israel and the Palestinians agreed the Oslo Accords in 1993, control of Gaza was handed to the Palestinian Authority (PA). In 2005, Israel performed a unilateral withdrawal from Gaza, uprooting all of its troops and thousands of settlers . Within months, Hamas won parliamentary elections in Gaza and aggressively seized control of the territory from the PA. In response, Israel imposed a strict blockade on Gaza, which some argued was another form of occupation. What is the legal definition of 'occupation'? According to Article 42 of the 1907 Hague Regulations a territory is considered occupied "when it is actually placed under the authority of the hostile army". Israel is not a party to the Fourth Hague Convention but it's "considered customary international law" and, therefore it "still binds Israel", said Atlantic Council . What might happen next? There are fears that settler movements may seize the opportunity to try and return to Gaza , said Leonie Fleischmann on The Conversation . Since Israel began its "onslaught" in the strip, settler groups have been calling for the resettlement of Gaza and although it's "not yet clear" whether Netanyahu plans to allow the establishment of civilian settlements there, "historical precedent makes this a very real possibility". Some have speculated, however, that the "threat of full occupation" is just part of a "strategy" to pressure Hamas to make concessions in "stalled talks", said Hugo Bachega, the BBC's Middle East correspondent. "We don't want to govern it. We don't want to be there as a governing body," Netanyahu has said. We "want to hand it over to Arab forces that will govern it properly without threatening us and giving Gazans a good life." How these aims are realised is less than clear, as Jonathan Sacerdoti noted in The Spectator . "Politically", the notion of "long-term Israeli security control over Gaza" without annexation or direct governance presents an "unsolved riddle: who will take responsibility for civil life once the guns fall silent"?

title: Trump tantra
creator: Anand Mishra
description: Donald Trump’s fanbase in India had begun to ebb even before the tariff war, and the real unravelling started when he claimed to have brokered peace between India and Pakistan during Operation Sindoor.
content: Dear readers, Those blowing the trumpet for Donald Trump in India have been, well, trumped. The US President’s announcement this week of a 50 per cent tariff on India has left his Indian superfans scrambling for new mantras. Until recently, some were busy performing yagnas and chanting the Mahamrityunjay mantra for his re-election. Now, they find themselves in need of a new hymn sheet. As Trump turned up the heat over India’s Russian oil purchases, social media was quick to strike back with a flurry of new barbs. “Tariff TANTRUMP” did the rounds, as did a Hindi riff inspired by an old film song: “ Trump Hai Ki Maanta Nahin, Bharat ko Jaanta Nahin ”—a reminder that Trump doesn’t quite see reality, and doesn’t even know India. The memes practically wrote themselves: “ Trump Ka Tariff Bam, Arthavyavastha Ka Niklega Dum? ” (Will Trump’s tariff bomb will shake up the economy?) After the 50 per cent tariff news broke, Minister of State (Agriculture) Bhagirath Chaudhary addressed reporters outside Parliament: “It is not unknown why Trump is rattled ( baukhlaaye huye hain) . Trump will soon find out what a man of determination and firmness Modi ji is. The Prime Minister isn’t about to blink for anyone, least of all Trump.” So much for the celebrated chemistry between Modi and Trump. We now have what you might call Trumpistry—the art of falling out in public. Meanwhile, AAP Rajya Sabha MP and Lovely Professional University Chancellor Ashok Kumar Mittal dashed off an open letter to Trump, warning that if Indians imposed strategic restrictions on American business, Washington, DC, would feel a far more “severe” pinch. The government, for its part, declared the targeting of India “unjustified and unreasonable”, promising to safeguard national interests. Online, the jibes kept coming: “ Trump Chacha Zoom Kar Lena (Zoom in, Uncle Trump),” one post on X advised, while another quipped, “Yeh trade war nahi , TRP war hai! [This is a TRP war!]” But there’s more to this than Trump’s theatrics. Something’s definitely cooking. For years, fascination with Trump in India has bordered on the surreal. Trump Towers now dot the skylines of Mumbai, Gurugram, and Pune; Gurugram even claims two, rivalling New York. Plans for a third tower in Noida are underway. Just a year ago, as Trump sought re-election, right-wing groups across India organised pujas for his victory. One mahamandaleshwar led a havan (a Hindu fire ritual) in Delhi’s Shahdara, conch shells and vermilion at the ready, and Trump’s posters were adorned with “Friend Forever” captions featuring Modi. After the failed assassination attempt on Trump at a Pennsylvania rally last July, Delhi’s Hindu Sena held a special havan for Trump’s well-being, with priests chanting the Mahamrityunjay mantra 1.25 lakh times—just in case the Secret Service was running low on options. Even the diaspora joined in: a branch of Hindu Sena tried to hold a havan in California in 2020. Back in 2016, a Mumbai temple hosted two yagnas for Trump’s victory. If nothing else, he’s been good for the incense trade. Alas, the decade-long Indian romance with Trump’s strongman image has lost its lustre. Trump’s fanbase here had begun to ebb even before the tariff war, and the real unravelling started when he claimed to have brokered peace between India and Pakistan during Operation Sindoor. This blew up in Parliament: Rahul Gandhi challenged Modi to call out the lie, while the RJD MP Manoj Jha drew laughs comparing Trump to Chacha Chaudhary—the comic-book uncle whose brain works faster than a computer. “I can see all the negative traits of Chacha Chaudhary in Trump,” Jha quipped, proposing a tongue-in-cheek resolution to brand Trump the “epitaph of the greatest lawyer of the century”. Social media had long discovered Chaudhary Trump. AI-generated memes show him reclining on a charpoy in full Haryana regalia, receiving a Nobel Peace Prize desi style, or selling kulfi on YouTube. One viral video stars Trump in a white kurta and pagdi (turban), with “Chaudhary Trump Zindabad” emblazoned below. Another right-wing X handle, on June 24, shared “THE CEASEFIRE CHAUDHARY CHACHA TRUMP”, complete with Trump’s post about the Israel-Iran ceasefire. In Bihar, things took an even more theatrical turn: during the recent Special Intensive Revision of electoral rolls, a prankster in Samastipur district submitted an online application for a residence certificate in Trump’s name, complete with his real parents’ names—Frederick Christ Trump and Mary Anne MacLeod—and a listed address in Hassanpur village. The State administration, still red-faced over an earlier certificate issued to “Dog Babu”, registered an FIR with the Cyber Police. The opposition, led by the Congress, went to town calling it the ultimate proof of electoral fraud in Bihar. Of course, Trump is trending in more mundane ways, too. Amazon now sells a Chacha Trump Trucking Pullover Hoodie in case your wardrobe has a diplomatic incident. Indians like having someone to worship, and Trump’s fading will be sorely felt. Unless—this is just a lover’s tiff, and a Modi-Trump patch-up takes place. Let us know what you are rooting for: break-up or patch-up. Until the next one, Anand Mishra | Political Editor, Frontline We hope you’ve been enjoying our newsletters featuring a selection of articles that we believe will be of interest to a cross-section of our readers. title: Can Rahul Gandhi be penalised if 'vote chori' claims against Election Commission are proven wrong?

content: Rahul Gandhi alleged that there was 'vote chori' of over 1 lakh votes in Mahadevapura Assembly segment in Bangalore during the 2024 Lok Sabha elections. The Election Commission (EC) on Friday asked Congress MP and Leader of Opposition in Lok Sabha Rahul Gandhi to either sign a formal declaration under the law or apologise to the nation for levelling false allegations of large-scale electoral fraud. Karnataka Chief Electoral Officer issued a letter to Gandhi asking him to submit the evidence under oath under Rule 20 (3) (b) of the Registration of Electors Rules 1960. EC sources told ANI that if Gandhi believes that his allegations against the poll panel are true, he should have no problem in signing the declaration. “If Rahul Gandhi does not sign the Declaration, it would mean that he does not believe in his analysis and resultant conclusions and absurd allegations. In which case, he should apologise to the nation. Therefore, he has two options: Either sign the Declaration or apologise to the Nation for raising absurd allegations against ECI,” said the poll body. Rahul Gandhi’s response Gandhi reiterated his vote theft allegations and slammed the poll panel for demanding an affidavit under oath from him to support his claims. Speaking at the 'Vote Adhikar Rally’ in Bengaluru, Gandhi said, "I have taken the oath inside the Parliament and on the constitution, and EC is asking me to take an oath on the vote theft,” he said. Gandhi also alleged that the EC websites in Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan and Bihar have been shut down because they knew that if people started questioning based on data, then their entire structure would collapse. "If we get the electronic voter list then we will prove that the prime minister of this country has become the PM by way of theft,” he said. What were Gandhi’s allegations? Gandhi on Thursday made a presentation that he claimed proved there were 100,250 “stolen” votes in the Mahadevapura assembly segment of Bangalore (Central) Parliamentary constituency that helped the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) win the seat in 2024. His presentation also included names of the voters involved, prompting an immediate reaction from the Election Commission, which asked him to send a signed declaration and oath to the effect. “EC was colluding with the BJP to steal elections. In one assembly segment, 100,250-vote theft took place. This is the reason why EC doesn’t give us machine-readable data,” he said. Gandhi had presented the EPIC number of a person named Aditya Srivastava from Lucknow claiming that in addition to Karnataka, he was also a voter in UP. He even displayed his face, photograph, and EPIC number during the presentation. How did the EC react? The chief electoral officers (CEO) of Karnataka, Maharashtra and Haryana said they would initiate the necessary proceedings after Gandhi declares under oath that he believes the wrongful inclusions and exclusions cited by him to be "true to the best of his knowledge and belief". "You are kindly requested to sign and return the enclosed declaration/oath under Rule 20(3)(b) of the Registration of Electors Rules, 1960, along with the name(s) of such elector(s) so that necessary proceedings can be initiated," the three CEOs said in separate letters. Can Gandhi be penalised? Under Section 31 of the Representation of People Act, 1950, if a person makes false information regarding preparation, revision or correction of an electoral roll, or the inclusion or exclusion of any entry in or from an electoral roll, "A statement or declaration in writing which is false and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, he shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both” Constitutional law expert PDT Achary, however, told The Hindu that these rules do not apply in this situation. These rules apply till 30 days after draft rolls are published. “In this case elections were held 15 months back (Lok Sabha polls 2024) and the Congress party has investigated the entire issue on its own now. These rules have no application whatsoever to the present case,” he said. Former Chief Election Commissioner OP Rawat also told The Hindu that the rule quoted by the EC is more applicable in cases like the Special Intensive Revision of Electoral Rolls, which is currently ongoing in Bihar.

title: Two charts that lay bare the threat posed by radical right parties to western democracies

content: In the 2024 UK general election, Reform came third with a 14% share of the vote, capturing five seats in the House of Commons . This was a breakthrough election for the party. In the previous general election in 2019, when it was known as the Brexit party, it won a 2% vote share and captured no parliamentary seats at all. This success is part of a trend. Radical right-wing populist parties are making gains in elections across many democracies and, in plenty of cases, they’re winning power. Giorgia Meloni’s Brothers of Italy has been in government in Italy since the election of September 2022, when they took 26% of the vote and captured 119 seats in the national parliament. In the National Assembly elections of June 2024, Marine Le Pen’s National Rally increased its representation from 89 seats to 125 seats. And in the Netherlands, the Freedom Party (PVV), led by right-wing populist Geert Wilders won the largest vote share in 2023 with 24%, capturing 37 seats in the House of Representatives. Perhaps most significantly, Donald Trump won the US presidential election in November 2024 with a rightwing populist agenda – a victory that has created turmoil in American politics and the economy, along with the rest of the world. title: Taiwan faces a precarious future – whether or not US and China continue on path to conflict
creator: Kerry Brown, Professor of Chinese Politics; Director, Lau China Institute, King's College London
description: The issue of Taiwan is looking more precarious and worrying.
content: Taiwan has often compared itself to being a “shrimp between two whales”. That expression has never been more apt than today with the US and China – which considers Taiwan to be part of its territory – locked in a standoff over the future of the island.At an event I attended some years ago, a Chinese scholar remarked when the issue of the US-China rivalry came up that they believed there was an African saying: “When two elephants are either having a fight, or making love, the grass around them gets trampled.” It was best for everyone, they advised the other attendees, for the two superpowers to have a workmanlike, unexciting relationship rather than take the risk of things getting too friendly or hostile. But whether or not the current period of conflict continues or the US and China magically become more aligned, the challenges facing Taiwan are severe.First off, Taiwan is itself in a period of domestic turbulence. The government of Taiwanese president William Lai Ching-te, leader of the Democratic Progressive party, was elected in January 2024 with a little over 40% of the vote. This was considerably less than his predecessor from the same party, Tsai Ing-wen.One of the main opposition leaders, Ke Wen-je of the Taiwan People’s party, has since then been arrested on corruption charges. He is accused of accepting half a million US dollars in bribes during his term as mayor of Taipei as well as misreporting campaign finances during his presidential run.Most recently, in late July, recall votes were held where citizens in 24 districts of Taiwan chose whether or not to remove their legislator from office. This is the result of a law in Taiwan stipulating a new vote if 10% of the electorate in a specific constituency express dissatisfaction at the previous outcome. Activists supporting the government mobilised to achieve this. The votes seem to be associated with frustration that, while the Democratic Progressive party controls the presidency, it cannot get legislation through a parliament dominated by its opponents. All of the votes were directed at seats held by the Kuomintang, the main opposition party in recent years that is accused by its critics of being pro-China. Not a single seat was overturned. When the steady nationalism of Xi Jinping’s leadership in Beijing is factored in, with its conviction that the global influence of the west is slowly declining and the east – dominated by China – is in the nascent, one can see why the issue of Taiwan might look more precarious and worrying. This is regardless of the various predictions that 2027 is the date that China has set to go for reunification.Ambiguous US positionFor the US, President Donald Trump’s fixation has remained on correcting what he sees as China’s unfair trade advantages with its largest single economic partner – something he has long talked about. The White House proclaimed in March, when the first set of trade negotiations with China concluded after tariffs were imposed by both sides, that: “for too long, unfair trade practices and America’s massive trade deficit with China have fuelled the offshoring of American jobs and the decline of our manufacturing sector.” The aim at the most recent set of talks in Stockholm, Sweden, in late July was to drive towards a new deal. Trump has also reportedly talked of taking a huge delegation of business people to China at some point later in 2025. This is despite the fact that so far since his inauguration in January, and despite many reasons to talk, Xi and Trump have yet to physically meet. Taiwanese people are therefore right to feel increasingly uneasy. Under Trump’s predecessor, Joe Biden, they received verbal commitments that the US would come to Taiwan’s aid if it was attacked. This was not formal US policy, which has long maintained an ambiguous stance on Taiwan. Ambiguity has returned with a vengeance under Trump. His secretary of defence, Pete Hegseth, has said that the US stands by Taiwan. But these days in Washington all roads lead to the Oval Office, and Trump’s stance is far harder to predict. If China were to dangle a trade deal in front of the US president – committing to buy more US goods, put in more investment that is non-problematic on security grounds in the US and generally abide by American demands – would Trump be able to resist? It could be presented as a historic achievement, a new concordant between the world’s two greatest powers who had seemed until then set on conflict and clash. There might even be the much desired Nobel Peace Prize in it for the US leader. Trump, for his part, appears increasingly reluctant to back Taiwan in ways that risk provoking Beijing. Lai delayed a trip to Latin America in July after the Trump administration reportedly told him to cancel a proposed stopover in New York. And the US cancelled a meeting with Taiwan’s defence minister one month earlier.The likelihood remains that, if a real crisis occurs, then the US will climb down from the middle wall and do something to defend Taiwan. Any trade deal between Beijing and Washington will also probably be a highly circumscribed one. China is not an easy partner to negotiate with, and it is unlikely to offer Trump the kind of capitulation he is seeking. Even so, these are very unpredictable times. The key calculation going forward will be the simple one of what the US gains and loses from all its relationships – and that includes Taiwan.Kerry Brown does not work for, consult, own shares in or receive funding from any company or organisation that would benefit from this article, and has disclosed no relevant affiliations beyond their academic appointment.

President William Lai Ching-te leads a divided nation after winning just under 40% support against Tsai Ing-wen. Opposition leader Ke Wen-je faces arrest on bribery allegations, while legislative recall efforts target Kuomintang members amidst nationalist sentiments from China's Xi Jinping.
ai_content:
As tensions simmer between the United States and China, Taiwan finds itself caught in the crossfire, grappling with internal strife and external pressures. In January 2024, President William Lai Ching-te assumed office representing the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), securing only slightly more than 40% of the popular vote—a stark contrast to his DPP predecessor, Tsai Ing-wen. The political climate within Taiwan remains volatile; one significant development involves Ke Wen-je, former Mayor of Taipei and prominent figure in the Taiwan People's Party (TPP). Accused of taking $500,000 in bribes and falsifying campaign finance reports, Ke Wen-je now confronts legal repercussions following his arrest on corruption charges.
The situation further escalated when recall elections took place across 24 districts in late July, allowing voters to decide whether legislators would remain in office based on a newly enacted law requiring such action if 10% of constituents expressed discontentment. These recalls stemmed largely from frustrations regarding the DPP's inability to pass legislation despite holding the presidency—an obstacle attributed to a parliamentary system controlled predominantly by rival parties, notably the Kuomintang (KMT).
The KMT, historically seen as pro-China, faced no successful recall attempts, suggesting a complex interplay of local politics beyond simple partisan divides. Meanwhile, the broader geopolitical context looms large, with China's President Xi Jinping fostering a strong nationalist agenda that casts Taiwan as an integral part of its sovereign territory. As these dynamics unfold, Taiwan navigates a delicate balance between asserting its autonomy and managing relationships with global powers.
